exchanges.user:
Been a few days since I decided to try therapy or coaching or whatever this is. Work has been completely insane - three deadline extensions that got yanked back, client wants to redesign everything we already finished. I'm running on coffee and spite at this point.

Also just moved to Portland last month. Still don't know anyone here really. The apartment is fine but everything feels temporary, you know? Like I haven't actually landed yet. Going through boxes and finding stuff from the old place in Denver makes me feel kind of untethered.

Anyway. The work thing is what's killing me. Can't sleep, my chest gets tight around 4pm every day like clockwork. Coworkers are stressed too but somehow I'm the one spiraling. Don't know if I'm actually worse at handling pressure or if I'm just more aware I'm drowning.

What am I even doing here. Need some actual clarity on whether this is normal stress or if I'm actually broken.
exchanges.assistant:
**Work pressure:** Three yanked deadlines and a full redesign after completion—that's not just stress, that's chaos being dumped on you. The 4pm chest tightness feels like your body's alarm system going off at a predictable time, probably when the day's damage becomes clear. You asked if you're worse at handling pressure or just more aware you're drowning—I'm curious what makes you think it might be the second one. What do you notice in yourself that your coworkers might be missing in themselves?

**The move:** A month in Portland, still in boxes, everything feeling temporary—that word "untethered" lands. It's hard to deal with work chaos when you don't have roots down yet, when home doesn't quite feel like home. The Denver stuff surfacing probably isn't helping. What did you leave behind there, besides the physical place?

**The "am I broken" question:** You're running on coffee and spite through multiple whiplash deadlines while living somewhere new with no support network and your nervous system is screaming at you every afternoon. That's not broken—that's actually a pretty coherent response to an objectively terrible situation. But I hear you wanting to know: is this within normal range or is something deeper going on? What would change for you if you knew the answer to that?

One thing that might help with the 4pm chest tightness: when it hits tomorrow, try this—name 5 things you can see, 4 things you can touch, 3 you can hear, 2 you can smell, 1 you can taste. It's called grounding. Your body's doing something intense in that moment and this gives it a different channel. Not a fix, just a tool for when the alarm goes off. Worth trying?

the move was supposed to be good for me. new job, fresh start, all that. but the new job is imploding and i don't have anyone here to vent to so it's just spinning in my head 24/7. the tight chest is back today already even though it's only 2pm.

Grounding isn't about making panic vanish, it's about riding it out without it taking over completely. The fact that you used it again today means you've got a tool now. Keep it.

**Work implosion:** Client sends midnight feedback saying everything's wrong, your manager folds instead of pushing back, and now you're redoing finished work. That "we'll figure it out tomorrow" with no plan is leadership failure, not your failure. You're caught in a system where the boundaries aren't being held and all that chaos is landing on you. The chest tightness starting at 2pm today instead of 4pm—that's your body saying "I know what's coming." It's anticipating the hit. That makes sense given what's happening.

**Transaction-people vs real people:** The barista remembering your oat milk order hitting you that way—I get it. It highlighted the gap between "someone knows my coffee" and "someone knows me." And then your sister calls and you can't tell her the truth because she's got her own stuff and you don't want to be a burden. So you said "yeah, fine" and now you're carrying it alone. What would it be like to tell her even 10% of what's actually happening? Not dumping everything, just cracking the door open a little?

**Fresh start turning sour:** You moved for a new job and a reset, and the job is collapsing under you while you're still trying to find your footing in a new city. The thing that was supposed to anchor you is the thing that's destabilizing you. No wonder it's spinning in your head—you don't have people there to help you process it out loud, so it just loops internally. That's exhausting.

exchanges.assistant:

Background dread still sucks, but it leaves you room to think—that's the difference between being underwater and treading water. The fact that you set the reminder and actually did it even when the tightness wasn't there yet? That's you building a practice, not just reacting to crisis. Keep that going.

**Work chaos eating itself:** The client demanding changes, then reversing those changes back to what you had two weeks ago—that's not work, that's organizational dysfunction. You're stuck in a loop where the problem isn't the work itself, it's that no one above you is holding a boundary with the client. Your manager's "defensive" response instead of "this is unsustainable" just confirmed to everyone that you're all supposed to absorb this without pushback. That window joke where nobody actually laughed—that's a team signaling they're all drowning together but no one's allowed to name it. You're not imagining this. It's as bad as it feels.

**Your sister:** "You've always been like that" is an interesting response. What do you think she meant by that? Sometimes when people say that, they're recognizing a pattern they've seen in you before—maybe you tend to go it alone, or you take on too much before reaching out. She didn't make it worse, and you're planning a video call this weekend, which is movement. That 10% you shared got received. What would it be like to share another 10% on the call?

**The boxes:** You keep planning to unpack and then you don't. Here's what I'm wondering—what would unpacking mean to you? Because sometimes not unpacking is about more than just not having time. It can be about not committing to being here yet, especially when "here" doesn't feel stable. The job is imploding, you don't have roots, and unpacking makes it real. Does that resonate at all, or is it really just an energy thing?

One small thing to try before the weekend: pick one box. Not "unpack the apartment," just one box. Doesn't matter which. See what happens when you make it smaller than "this weekend I'll do it all." Sometimes the activation energy for "all the boxes" is too high, but "one box" is doable. Worth testing?

exchanges.assistant:

**Work breathing room:** The project manager asking smart questions and your manager actually pushing back on timelines—those are structural changes, not just you white-knuckling through it. "Treading water with your head above the surface sometimes" is a completely different state than "drowning with no one holding a boundary." You're still in it, but the conditions changed. That's real.

**Grounding "failing" at 6pm:** Here's what I'm hearing—you did the 2pm grounding, it worked, then the tightness came back harder at 6pm and your brain said "see, this doesn't actually work, you're failing, nothing changes, you'll feel like this forever." That spiral makes sense, but let's look at what actually happened. The grounding tool isn't a vaccine—it's not supposed to prevent anxiety from ever showing up again. It's a way to ride it out when it does. The 6pm tightness coming back doesn't mean the 2pm grounding failed. It means something triggered your nervous system later in the day. What happened around 6pm? Was there a work thing, a thought, something that landed wrong?

The spiral afterward—"nothing actually changes, I'm just gonna feel like this forever"—that's catastrophic thinking kicking in when you're already vulnerable. When that hits, it feels true, but it's not evidence. It's your brain in threat mode. One thing that might help: when the tightness comes back like that, do the grounding again. Not because the first one failed, but because your body needs it again. You can use the tool more than once in a day. It's not a sign of failure—it's just what that day required.

**The boxes:** You did one box, felt good for a day, then stopped. And now the voice is saying "why bother if I'm just gonna stay anxious anyway." That's the same catastrophic thinking from the 6pm spiral—it's leaking into the unpacking question. Here's what I want to reflect back: you unpacked one box and it didn't cure your anxiety. You proved to yourself you could start something without finishing all of it. Those are real things, even if they didn't fix everything.

The apartment not feeling like home yet—that makes sense. You've been there a month, most of your stuff is still in boxes, your job is chaos, and you don't have roots down. Home isn't just a place, it's a feeling of stability and connection, and you don't have much of either right now. Unpacking won't create that feeling by itself, but staying in boxes might be keeping you in "temporary" mode when what you actually need is to commit to being here, even while it's hard. What would one more box this week look like? Not to fix the anxiety, just to take one more step toward settling in.
